title: Electron crashes when restarting to update Insiders on macOS

- 3 Electron crashes were reported by the OS.

No crash dumps in Crashpad, will append the OS crash details.

title: Clicking a tool call for a task run should open the corresponding terminal instance.

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body: Testing #263327 Add a link or similar affordance in the tool call result so that clicking it for a task run opens the corresponding terminal instance. If the terminal is hidden and a task fails, clicking should bring it up so I can navigate directly to the failed task. I can always toggle terminal visibility and navigate to the failed task, but I opened this in case you’d like to consider adding it since our tool call UI already supports this (e.g., Terminal Run tool calls link to the Settings editor to display approved commands ).

title: Deleted files reappear after restart when using Copilot Chat in VS Code
body: **Describe the bug** When using GitHub Copilot Pro in VS Code, I noticed that some files I have deleted reappear after I restart VS Code. It seems that Copilot Chat is restoring them from its session/cache, even though I explicitly removed them from my workspace. **Steps to reproduce** 1. Open a project in VS Code with Copilot Pro enabled. 2. Create a few files. 3. Delete one or more of them. 4. Close VS Code. 5. Reopen VS Code and continue with Copilot Chat. 6. The previously deleted files reappear. **Expected behavior** Deleted files should not reappear. Copilot Chat should respect the current state of the workspace and not restore removed files. **Environment** * VS Code version: 1.103.2 * GitHub Copilot extension version: Copilot 1.364.0 / Copilot Chat 0.30.3 * OS: Windows 11 **Additional context** It looks like Copilot Chat is caching some file state and rehydrating them on session restore. This can cause confusion when working on real projects, since removed files come back unexpectedly.

title: Change Emmet HTML boilerplate (!) cursor placement from <head> to <body>
body: ### Feature Request ISSUE : When I press "!" and hit enter in a .html file , the Emmet gives me the HTML Boilerplate. But the Cursor stays inside the head, and when anything is typed, the device-width changes/is replaced with our typed-text which disturbs our workflow. Most of the time, we( developers) want to start writing code inside body. Because of this, we have to manually move the cursor down every time, which is a bit irritating. Solution: It would be better if the cursor moved into the body tag automatically and instantly. Here are 2 images to help understand the problem better: [ CURRENT ISSUE ] : As you can see above, the cursor is placed in the 'content' and "Device Width" is pre-selected .Anything we type even a by-mistake key press replaces the "device-width". [ POSSIBLE SOLUTION ]: [ Edit: The cursor didn't appear when I tried to screenshot the second time, so used comments. I hope my issue has been clearly presented ]

title: Chat editor lifecycle

labels.name: polish
labels.description: Cleanup and polish issue

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The Chat Editor is a thin wrapper around the Chat Widget with limited editor features. While we are encouraging its adoption for Coding Agents and CLI sessions, we should improve the Chat Editor's lifecycle handling. It's similar to the custom editor and notebook, the content of which is contributed by extensions and is, by nature, asynchronous. Making the experience smooth requires efforts, including but not limited to:

- [ ] Proper editor input swap (clear previous input instantly) and placeholder for loading state https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264570 
- [ ] Persist and restore view state per editor input
  - [ ] prompt in chat editor input box https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264643
  - [ ] chat view type
  - [ ] scroll position
- [ ] Move editor across editor groups should persist state
- [ ] ? Support splitting chat editor
- [ ] Proper uri label rendering for chat editor input uri (e.g., in Timeline view)

title: Testing: Clear all todos button implemented as link
body: Testing #264450 Not sure if this is intentional, but given the testing item: "The button’s title and aria-label should both be “Clear all todos”." thought I should call out that the clear all todos "button" is implemented as a link with a role button and there's no `title` attribute. I'll tag in @meganrogge as a sanity check, but my understanding of a11y best practices is you should always use the correct semantic HTML element rather than adding a role to a non semantic element –– aka prefer `

title: Testing: Overlapping tooltips on clear todo button

title: Fix external chat sessions contributing to local history
body:
External provider chat sessions (e.g., from GitHub Copilot, OpenAI plugins) were incorrectly being saved to the local chat history when cleared, causing them to appear in the user's chat history alongside local sessions.

## Problem

The `clearSession` method in `ChatServiceImpl` only checked if a session's `initialLocation` was Panel or Editor to determine whether to save it to history, without considering whether the session originated from an external content provider:

```typescript
// Previous logic - saves ALL Panel/Editor sessions to history
if (model.initialLocation === ChatAgentLocation.Panel || model.initialLocation === ChatAgentLocation.Editor) {
    // Save to history...
}
```

This meant external provider sessions loaded via `loadSessionForResource` were being persisted to local history even though they should remain isolated to their respective providers.

## Solution

Added an `isExternalSession()` helper method that checks if a session exists in the `_contentProviderSessionModels` collection, and modified the `clearSession` condition to exclude external sessions from history persistence:

```typescript
// New logic - only saves LOCAL Panel/Editor sessions to history  
const isExternal = this.isExternalSession(sessionId);
if ((model.initialLocation === ChatAgentLocation.Panel || model.initialLocation === ChatAgentLocation.Editor) && !isExternal) {
    // Save to history only if not external...
}
```

## Behavior Changes

- **External sessions**: No longer saved to local chat history when cleared
- **Local sessions**: Continue to be saved to history exactly as before
- **Workspace recovery**: External sessions still preserved in workspace state via `saveState()` for proper restoration

## Testing

The fix handles various scenarios correctly:
- Multiple external providers (GitHub Copilot, OpenAI, custom plugins)
- Mixed local and external sessions in the same workspace
- Edge cases like empty provider collections
- Different session locations (Panel, Editor, Notebook, Terminal)

This ensures external provider sessions remain isolated from local history while preserving all existing functionality for local chat sessions.

title: Feature Request: Option to auto Close Find Dialog After Search
body: Type: Feature Request Currently, when using **Ctrl+F** to search in VS Code, the editor leaves the user inside the Find dialog after a match is found. This requires pressing **Escape** or clicking the close button to return focus to the editor. I am requesting a new feature setting in the editor that allows users to automatically close the Find dialog after a search completes. This would make the **Find** action behave more like pressing **F3** or **Shift+F3** for Find Next/Previous. --- ## Current Behavior - When searching for text (e.g., "alpha") using **Ctrl+F**, the editor shows the Find dialog. - The dialog indicates the number of matches found and allows additional actions. - Focus remains in the Find dialog until manually closed by the user. --- ## Expected Behavior with New Setting Enabled - After performing a search, focus moves directly to the found text in the editor. - The user can immediately continue editing without manually closing the Find dialog. - If no results are found: - A status message, dialog, or sound is provided (user-configurable). - Screen readers receive accessible feedback, and optionally a tone can be played. --- ## Proposed Setting Name and Example A new boolean setting could be introduced: ```jsonc // settings.json "editor.find.closeOnResult": true ``` - **true** → After a successful search, the Find dialog automatically closes and focus is placed in the editor at the found text. - **false** (default) → Current behavior, the Find dialog stays open after a search. --- ## Benefits - Improved workflow efficiency by eliminating extra keystrokes. - Consistent behavior with **F3** / **Shift+F3** searches. - Better accessibility for screen reader users through direct feedback and reduced navigation overhead. title: Find: “Search wraps” off jumps to previous match and gives no accessible feedback when Loop set to false

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

labels.name: editor-find
labels.description: Editor find operations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Type: Bug **Summary** When `editor.find.loop` is **disabled** (Search wraps OFF), pressing **F3** (“Find Next”) at or after the last match does **not** fail in place. Instead, if the caret is moved below the last match and **F3** is pressed, VS Code jumps **backward** to the previous/last match. Similarly, pressing **Shift+F3** (“Find Previous”) at or before the first match also does **not** fail in place. Instead, if the caret is moved above the first match and **Shift+F3** is pressed, VS Code jumps **forward** to the first/next match. Additionally, there is **no accessible status/announcement** to indicate that no further results were found (JAWS and NVDA do not speak anything and no sound is played). --- ## Environment - **OS:** Windows 10 (x64) - **VS Code:** Latest stable release - **Settings relevant to repro:** - `"editor.find.loop": false` - `"editor.accessibilitySupport": "on"` (or auto; VS Code detects screen reader) --- ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a new file with exactly these three lines (identical text): ``` alpha alpha alpha ``` 2. Press **Ctrl+F**, type `alpha`, and ensure focus is on the first line (top of file). **Forward search case (F3):** 3. Press **F3** repeatedly to move to the next occurrences until you reach the **third (last)** `alpha`. - **Observed:** focus lands on the last match; pressing **F3** again appears to do nothing (and JAWS/NVDA announce nothing). 4. Now **press Arrow Down** to move the caret **below** the last occurrence (i.e., to an empty line after line 3). 5. Press **F3** again. - **Observed:** focus **jumps backward** to the last/previous match instead of failing in place. - **Also observed:** **no accessible announcement** (JAWS and NVDA do not announce that no further results were found). **Backward search case (Shift+F3):** 6. Place the caret at the **top of the file**, before the first `alpha`. 7. Press **Shift+F3** to search backward. - **Observed:** instead of failing in place, focus **jumps forward** to the first/next match. - **Also observed:** **no accessible announcement** (JAWS and NVDA do not announce that no further results were found). --- ## Expected Behavior - With `"editor.find.loop": false`, pressing: - **F3 at/after the last match** should not move, and should present clear feedback. - **Shift+F3 at/before the first match** should not move, and should present clear feedback. - Feedback should include: - A visible status message (e.g., “No further results” / “Reached end of document; no wrap”). - An **accessible announcement** via the appropriate live region so screen readers (JAWS, NVDA) announce that no further results were found. - (Optionally) trigger an **audio cue** for “search no results,” if enabled. --- ## Actual Behavior - **F3** at/after the last match jumps backward instead of failing in place. - **Shift+F3** at/before the first match jumps forward instead of failing in place. - In both cases: - No accessible announcement is made (JAWS and NVDA are silent). - No visible/non-modal status message is announced to assistive tech. --- ## Accessibility Impact - Users relying on screen readers receive **no feedback** that the search has ended, which is misleading and results in extra navigation and confusion. - The unexpected **reverse jump** violates the directional semantics of **F3** (“Find Next”) and **Shift+F3** (“Find Previous”), disorienting keyboard/screen-reader users who depend on predictable focus movement. --- ## Notes & Variations Tested - Repro occurs with a single repeated token (`alpha`) on three consecutive lines; also occurs with separated matches. - Behavior is the same with **Find in Editor** (Ctrl+F). - Occurs with extensions disabled (`code --disable-extensions`). - `"editor.find.seedSearchStringFromSelection"` setting does not affect the repro. - The issue occurs in **both directions** (F3 and Shift+F3). --- ## Suggested Fix / Acceptance Criteria - When `"editor.find.loop": false`: - **F3 at/after last match** does not change selection/caret, does not jump backward. - **Shift+F3 at/before first match** does not change selection/caret, does not jump forward. - A **status message** is presented (and exposed to the accessibility tree) such that JAWS and NVDA (and other AT) announce “No further results” (or similar). - (Optional) Fire the **audio cue** for no results, if audio cues are enabled. - Add/adjust automated tests to cover: - Non-wrapping forward search at end - Non-wrapping backward search at beginning - Accessible announcements on search termination --- VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

title: Enable rename and delete actions for chat history items
body:
The rename action was only available for current chat sessions but not for history items in the Chat Sessions tree view, despite being available in the legacy "Show Chats" picker. This created an inconsistent user experience.

## Changes Made

### Enable Rename for History Items
- Removed the `ChatContextKeys.isHistoryItem.isEqualTo(false)` condition from the rename action's menu registration, allowing it to appear for both current and history chat sessions
- Added proper session ID handling in `RenameChatSessionAction` to strip the `history-` prefix before calling `setChatSessionTitle()`, consistent with how other actions handle history items
- Updated the comment to reflect that history items are now supported

### Add Delete Action for History Items  
- Implemented `DeleteChatSessionAction` with complete context handling following the same patterns as the rename action
- Added menu registration for the delete action, but only for history items (`ChatContextKeys.isHistoryItem.isEqualTo(true)`) to prevent accidental deletion of active sessions
- Uses the existing `chatService.removeHistoryEntry()` method with proper session ID processing

## Before and After

**Before:** Users could only rename the current chat session. History items under the "History" node had limited context menu options.

**After:** Users can now rename both current and history chat sessions, and delete history items directly from the Chat Sessions tree context menu, providing a consistent experience with the legacy picker.

The implementation follows existing VS Code patterns and includes proper error handling and logging.

Fixes #264784.

title: Make chat session "new chat" actions available on all provider views and scope to correct provider
body:
Previously, the "new chat" actions (Open New Chat in New Window, Open New Chat Editor to the Side, New Chat Editor button, and Ctrl+N) were only available when viewing local chat sessions. Users couldn't access these quick actions when viewing Claude sessions, coding agent sessions, or other external provider sessions.

Additionally, when these actions were triggered from external provider views, they always created new chat sessions with the default copilot provider instead of the provider associated with the current view.

This change:

1. **Makes actions available on all provider views** by updating the `when` conditions from exact view matching to regex pattern matching that matches any view starting with `workbench.view.chat.sessions.`

2. **Ensures new chats are scoped to the correct provider** by extracting the provider type from the current view context and passing it as `chatSessionType` when creating new editors

## How it works

The actions now:
- Use regex pattern `^workbench\.view\.chat\.sessions\.` to match all provider views
- Extract provider type from current view ID using `contextKeyService.getContextKeyValue('view')`
- Pass the provider type as `chatSessionType` in editor options
- The chat editor automatically locks to the appropriate provider using the existing `lockToCodingAgent()` mechanism

## Result

Users can now access "new chat" actions from any provider view (local, Claude, coding agent, etc.) and the new chat sessions will interact with the same provider as the view they were triggered from, providing a seamless experience across different AI assistants.

Fixes #264787.

title: Allow deleting and renaming history from chat session view
body:
The chat history quick pick provides delete and rename options for history entries, but the Chat Sessions view in the sidebar only had delete functionality for history items. This PR adds both delete and rename actions to history items in the Chat Sessions tree view for complete session management.

## Changes Made

### Added DeleteChatSessionAction
- Created a new `DeleteChatSessionAction` class following the same pattern as existing session actions
- Uses `Codicon.x` icon for visual consistency with VS Code delete operations
- Shows confirmation dialog before deletion to prevent accidental removal
- Handles both marshalled context from menu system and direct context calls
- Properly extracts session IDs from history items (removes 'history-' prefix)

### Added Rename Support for History Sessions
- Modified `RenameChatSessionAction` to handle history sessions by extracting actual session ID from 'history-' prefix
- Updated menu registration to show rename option for all local sessions (including history items)
- History sessions now support inline renaming with validation and error handling

### Menu Integration
- Registered delete action with `MenuId.ChatSessionsMenu` using inline group for direct icon display
- Uses context condition `ChatContextKeys.isActiveSession.isEqualTo(false)` to show delete only for history items
- Updated rename action to show for all local sessions: `ChatContextKeys.sessionType.isEqualTo('local')`
- Maintains separation: active sessions show rename only, history items show both rename and delete

### Service Integration  
- Leverages existing `chatService.removeHistoryEntry()` method for actual deletion
- Uses existing `chatService.setChatSessionTitle()` method for renaming
- Added proper error handling and logging for both operations
- Fixed list refresh by calling `chatSessionsService.notifySessionItemsChanged('local')` after successful operations
- Registered action in `chat.contribution.ts` for proper initialization

## User Experience

**Before**: History items in Chat Sessions view had no actions available
**After**: History items show both rename and delete icons on hover:
1. **Rename**: Allows inline editing of session titles with validation
2. **Delete (x)**: Shows confirmation dialog then permanently removes the history item from both UI and storage
3. **Immediate UI updates**: Both operations immediately update the UI list to reflect changes
4. **Consistent behavior**: Matches the functionality already available in the chat history quick pick

This provides users with complete session management capabilities directly from the Chat Sessions sidebar view.

Fixes #264644.

title: Contribute "Getting Started" items from extensions instead of hardcoded in core
body:
This PR addresses the architectural issue where "Getting Started" items in the chat panel were hardcoded in VS Code core instead of being contributed by extensions.

## Problem

The chat sessions view contained hardcoded getting started items:
- "Install Chat Extensions" 
- "Learn More About GitHub Copilot coding agent"

These items were directly embedded in `chatSessions.ts`, violating VS Code's principle of keeping core minimal and allowing extensions to contribute functionality.

## Solution

Created a new extension contribution system that allows extensions to contribute getting started items:

### 1. New Extension Point

```typescript
interface IChatGettingStartedItem {
    id: string;
    label: string;
    commandId: string;
    icon?: string;
    args?: any[];
    when?: string;
}
```

Extensions can now contribute via `package.json`:

```json
{
  "contributes": {
    "chatGettingStarted": [
      {
        "id": "install-extensions",
        "label": "Install Chat Extensions",
        "commandId": "chat.sessions.gettingStarted",
        "icon": "extensions"
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

### 2. Core Integration

- Removed hardcoded items from `chatSessions.ts`
- Added extension point handler that dynamically loads contributions
- Supports context-aware filtering via `when` conditions
- Maintains identical user experience

### 3. Example Extension

Created `extensions/chat-extensions-getting-started/` that provides the original functionality as extension contributions, demonstrating how chat-related extensions can contribute their own getting started content.

## Benefits

- **Modularity**: Chat-specific content moved out of core
- **Extensibility**: Any extension can contribute getting started items
- **Context Awareness**: Items can show/hide based on workspace conditions
- **Maintainability**: Extension authors control their own content lifecycle

The user experience remains exactly the same - the same items appear in the same location with the same functionality. The difference is architectural: items now come from extension contributions rather than being hardcoded in core.

Fixes #264793.

title: Fix chat session "Open to the Side" to respect user's side-by-side direction preference
body:
Updated the chat session context menu to use "Open to the Side" instead of "Open in New Editor Group" and fixed the implementation to respect the user's preferred side-by-side opening direction.

## Problem
The chat session context menu had two issues:
1. Used inconsistent terminology ("Open in New Editor Group" vs the standard "Open to the Side")
2. Always opened chat sessions to the right, ignoring the user's `workbench.editor.openSideBySideDirection` setting

## Solution
- Changed menu label to "Open to the Side" to match terminology used throughout VS Code
- Replaced hardcoded `GroupDirection.RIGHT` with `SIDE_GROUP` to follow VS Code's standard editor opening pattern
- Now respects the user's configured side-by-side direction preference (right or down)

This improves both UI consistency and user experience by honoring their preferred layout direction.

Fixes #264671.

title: [WIP] Chat sessions editor should auto-scroll
body:
## Chat Sessions Editor Auto-Scroll Fix

**Problem**: Chat sessions editor doesn't auto-scroll when new parts stream in during coding agent sessions.

**Root Cause Analysis**: 
- When locking to a coding agent (`lockToCodingAgent`), the chat mode is set to `ChatModeKind.Ask`
- In `chatEditor.ts`, auto-scroll is configured as: `autoScroll: mode => mode !== ChatModeKind.Ask`
- This means auto-scroll is **disabled** for Ask mode, which is used by coding agent sessions
- The `scrollLock` property is set based on this auto-scroll configuration

**Plan**:
- [x] Investigate current auto-scroll implementation
- [x] Identify root cause in lockToCodingAgent method
- [ ] Fix auto-scroll configuration for coding agent sessions 
- [ ] Test the fix with manual verification
- [ ] Ensure existing functionality is preserved

**Minimal Change Strategy**:
Modify the auto-scroll configuration in `chatEditor.ts` to enable auto-scroll for coding agent sessions while preserving existing behavior for regular Ask mode.

Fixes #264602.

title: Add Multi-Diff Editor view for Search Results using existing components
body:
Implements a multi-diff editor view for search results that shows each file as an individual diff editor with syntax highlighting and proper diff capabilities, while preserving the existing search editor functionality.

## Overview

This PR adds a **"View as Multi-Diff"** action to search editors that opens search results in a new multi-diff editor tab. Instead of replacing the existing search editor, this provides users with a choice between the traditional text-based view and a rich multi-diff view.

## Key Features

### Multi-Diff View
- Each search result file displays as an individual diff editor
- Original file content vs highlighted version showing search matches  
- Proper syntax highlighting for each file type
- Built-in diff editor features (folding, navigation, etc.)
- Virtualized rendering for performance with large result sets

### User Experience
- **Backward compatible**: Existing search editor functionality preserved
- **"View as Multi-Diff"** button in search editor toolbar
- Available via F1 command palette (`Search Editor: View as Multi-Diff`)
- Opens in new editor tab for side-by-side comparison

## Architecture

The implementation follows VS Code's existing multi-diff integration patterns (similar to SCM and Notebook) using the standard `MultiDiffEditorInput` rather than creating custom components:

1. **SearchMultiDiffSourceResolver** - Implements `IMultiDiffSourceResolver` to convert search results to multi-diff items
2. **SearchResultHighlighter** - Generates highlighted file versions with search matches marked using Unicode brackets (【match】)
3. **SearchMultiDiffSourceResolverContribution** - Registers the resolver with the multi-diff service
4. **OpenSearchResultsAsMultiDiffAction** - Provides the UI action and command

## Implementation Details

```typescript
// Uses existing MultiDiffEditorInput via standard pattern
const multiDiffSource = SearchMultiDiffSourceResolver.getMultiDiffSourceUri(searchResult);
await editorService.openEditor({ 
    label: 'Search Results',
    multiDiffSource 
});
```

The resolver converts search results to multi-diff items that show original file content versus highlighted versions where search matches are marked as text modifications, making them visible in the diff view.

## Benefits

- **Leverages existing components**: Uses battle-tested `MultiDiffEditorInput` instead of recreating functionality
- **Rich search experience**: Better visualization of search matches in context  
- **Non-invasive**: Zero impact on existing search editor users
- **Performance**: Leverages multi-diff editor's built-in virtualization
- **Proper integration**: Follows established patterns from SCM and Notebook multi-diff integrations
- **Familiar UX**: Reuses existing multi-diff editor patterns users know

This provides users with the enhanced search results experience while maintaining full backward compatibility and proper architectural integration with VS Code's existing multi-diff system.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.

title: Fix terminal suggest widget icon clipping with custom lineHeight
body:
The terminal suggest widget was incorrectly clipping icons when users set custom `terminal.integrated.lineHeight` values. This was most noticeable with common multiplier values like `1.1`.

![Before - Icons clipped with lineHeight 1.1](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/55842803-81fb-4494-bfff-2b20cd9c241f)

![After - Icons display correctly](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b9ba7131-854b-4b43-aebf-66af271ce5e6)

## Root Cause

The terminal suggest addon's `_getFontInfo()` method was incorrectly processing line height values. According to the terminal configuration documentation, `terminal.integrated.lineHeight` is "multiplied by the terminal font size to get the actual line-height in pixels" - meaning ALL values are multipliers, never pixels.

However, the logic was treating values ≥ 8 as pixel values instead of multipliers:

```typescript
// Before (incorrect)
if (lineHeight <= 1) {
    lineHeight = GOLDEN_LINE_HEIGHT_RATIO * fontSize;
} else if (lineHeight < MINIMUM_LINE_HEIGHT) { // Only values < 8
    lineHeight = lineHeight * fontSize;
}
// Values ≥ 8 were incorrectly used as-is (pixels)
```

## The Fix

Changed the logic to treat ALL values > 1 as multipliers:

```typescript
// After (correct)
if (lineHeight <= 1) {
    lineHeight = GOLDEN_LINE_HEIGHT_RATIO * fontSize;
} else { // ALL values > 1 are multipliers
    lineHeight = lineHeight * fontSize;
}
```

## Impact

- ✅ `lineHeight: 1.1` → Correctly converts to ~17px (1.1 × 15px font)
- ✅ `lineHeight: 8.5` → Before: 8.5px (wrong), After: 8.5 × fontSize (correct)  
- ✅ `lineHeight: 10` → Before: 10px (wrong), After: 10 × fontSize (correct)

The suggest widget sets `icon.style.height = lineHeightPx`, so proper line height calculation ensures icons aren't clipped and display at the correct size.

Fixes #255851.

title: if option was sent to terminal, wait for idle
body:
fix #264552

This was overly complicated and could cause the request to hang while waiting for a data event that likely already occurred. It's safer to just poll again until idle. 

cc @tyriar

title: Missing flags, missing details on flags
body: Testing #264149 Where does this info come from, do you expect it to match everything that I have available? man page has more useful detail: `Colorize the output. The optional argument when can be auto, never or always. If the when argument is omitted, it defaults to auto. The colors can be disabled; for the current built-in default see the --help output. See also the COLORS section.` As I look through the commands there are other differences but I won't list them all, I'm guessing it's expected to be imprecise

title: Opening coding agent session from workspace history disables chat panel
body:
